__data__.text: Claude List was born in Australia in 1902 to German and English parents. After his father's death in 1903, his mother remarried an German-born senior rugby league player, Francis Martin List, in 1907. The family, including Claude and his half-siblings, moved to New Zealand between 1915 and 1919. Claude started playing rugby league in Queensland at the age of 10 and continued to play in New Zealand after moving there. He played for the Kingsland Rovers, moving up from the third grade to the second grade by 1923. In 1924, he played on the wing and helped his team win the second grade knockout competition. He was selected for the Auckland Junior representative side and played in two matches against Hamilton juniors. In 1925, Claude made his senior debut for Kingsland in the B Division and was selected for the Auckland side, becoming one of the only players to be chosen from that grade. He scored multiple tries in his first few matches and was praised for his performance in a B team trial match. Despite being a newcomer to the senior game, he was considered for the New Zealand side to tour Australia. Claude went on to score tries in all three of Auckland's tour matches against West Coast, Canterbury, and Wellington. He was then chosen for the full Auckland side to play South Auckland and scored two tries in a 36-19 win.

In the continuation of Claude List's rugby league career, he played 16 matches for Kingsland in the 1926 season, scoring 11 tries and kicking a goal. He also made 4 appearances for Auckland, scoring 7 tries and being their equal leading try scorer. List was chosen for a New Zealand trial match and a B Team trial side, but ultimately missed selection for the New Zealand touring side. He continued to perform well in his matches for Kingsland and Auckland, with his skills and talent noted by various newspapers. Despite his impressive play, List did not make the New Zealand side that toured England and Wales, with the forwards ultimately causing more issues than the backs. List was eventually chosen for the Auckland squad to play Otago, scoring a try in their win, and later played in the centres against Canterbury, scoring 3 tries and impressing the Herald with his straight running and strong fending. The Herald suggested that with further coaching, List would develop into a brilliant attacking center three-quarter.

In the 1927 rugby league season, Claude List continued to excel as a center for Kingsland and Auckland, scoring numerous tries and impressing spectators and selectors with his straight running and strong fending. Despite his skill, he did not make the New Zealand touring side, but was chosen for the Auckland squad to play against various opponents. List's impressive play, including scoring multiple tries in several matches, led to him being considered one of the best centers in Auckland and a strong candidate for the New Zealand team. He was eventually selected to play for the North Island side against the South Island, where he scored a try in their victory. List's success in the B Division led to the recognition of other talented players in the lower ranks, and he was consistently praised for his contributions to his teams.

In the 1927 rugby league season, Claude List emerged as a standout center for Kingsland and Auckland, scoring numerous tries and impressing with his skill. Despite not making the New Zealand touring side, his impressive play led to his selection for the Auckland squad and eventually the North Island side. List's contributions included scoring multiple tries in several matches, including one in the North Island's victory over the South Island. His success highlighted the talent in the lower ranks and brought him recognition as one of the best centers in Auckland and a strong candidate for the New Zealand team. In 1928, List began the season with Kingsland and was considered a top candidate for the center position on the New Zealand team, eventually making his national debut in the first test against England and scoring a try in the upset victory.

In the 1927 rugby league season, Claude List emerged as a talented center for Kingsland and Auckland, scoring multiple tries and impressing with his skill. His performances led to his selection for the Auckland and North Island squads, and eventually, he made his national debut for New Zealand in 1928, becoming the first player to be selected while playing for a second-division club. List's contributions included scoring a try in New Zealand's upset victory over England in the first test. However, his performances were inconsistent, and he was criticized for poor decision-making in certain matches. Despite this, List's talent was evident, and he continued to be selected for higher-level teams, including the Auckland Provincial side and the Auckland side. However, he was eventually dropped from the New Zealand team due to injury or poor form. List's performances were a mix of brilliance and inconsistency, and he faced criticism for his decision-making and ball handling at times.

In 1931, Kingsland was forced to merge with Marist Old Boys due to the league's decision to reduce the number of senior teams and create a reserve grade competition. List joined Marist with the merger. He quickly became a key player for Marist, scoring multiple tries and impressing with his defensive work. His strong performances helped Marist win the 1931 Fox Memorial championship. List's play was characterized by his straight running, powerful attacks, and ability to create openings for his teammates. His performances led to his selection for the North Island team and he played a key role in their victory over the South Island. List's play was highly regarded by the selectors and he was considered a strong candidate for the New Zealand team for their upcoming series against England.

In the 1932 rugby league season, Claude List, a center for Marist, had impressive performances, including scoring multiple tries against Devonport and City. His strong play led to his selection for higher-level teams, including the North Island squad. List's performances were characterized by his straight running, powerful attacks, and ability to create openings for his teammates. He was eventually selected for the New Zealand team and scored a try in their upset victory over England in the first test. However, he was dropped from the team due to injury or poor form. List's performances continued to be strong, leading to his selection for the North Island team and his involvement in their victory over the South Island. He was considered a strong candidate for the New Zealand team for their upcoming series against England. List's play was highly regarded by the selectors and he was chosen to play in the first test against England. Despite New Zealand's loss in the match, List's performance was noted and he retained his place in the team for the second test. He scored both of New Zealand's tries in the second test, but the team still lost the match. List's play was consistently strong throughout the season, leading to his selection for various representative teams and his inclusion in the New Zealand side for the third test. Despite New Zealand's loss in the final test, List's performance was praised by the English financial manager. He returned to his Marist side to finish the season and continued to play for them in the following seasons. List's career as a representative player ended in 1933, but he continued to play senior club football for a further 9 seasons.

After the English tour, List returned to his Marist side and had a series of impressive performances, including scoring multiple tries in various matches. His play was crucial as Marist won several trophies and competitions. However, he faced criticism for his performance in a match against Ponsonby, with the selectors relying on his past successes. Despite this, he was selected for Auckland's matches against Taranaki and South Auckland, though Auckland lost the latter. List also had a dispute with the Marist club over financial issues and was suspended, leading to his transfer to Mount Albert United. He played as a forward for Mount Albert in the 1935 season, scoring 4 tries and kicking 1 conversion.

After being suspended by Marist, List transferred to Mount Albert United and played as a forward for the 1935 season, scoring 4 tries and kicking 1 conversion. Despite being suspended for several months, he eventually secured a transfer and was joined by some of his suspended teammates. Mount Albert had been seeking senior grade status, and they were allowed to enter the Roope Rooster competition. List played in various positions throughout the season, with his performance being praised in some matches and criticized in others due to handling errors. The season ended with Mount Albert losing the final match for the championship. In 1936, List began playing a mixture of senior and senior reserve grade matches for Mount Albert, and by 1938, he was 36 years old and had been playing senior rugby league for 14 seasons. He continued to play for Mount Albert until the 1941 season, where he played 19 games and scored 2 tries at the age of 39, making it his 17th season of senior football.

At the annual general meeting on February 20, 1941, Claude List received a trophy for his services, while his brother Francis won the award for the most consistent forward. Claude also won the C. Elwin Memorial Cup for the annual 100 yards championship. The 1941 season marked List's return to senior football after spending the previous season in the reserve grade due to the impact of World War II on senior sides. He played 19 games and scored 2 tries for Mount Albert, demonstrating his versatility by playing in various positions. His performances were praised in several matches, and he played his final game on June 20, 2023, against City-Otahuhu, where he was once again described as "prominent" among the forwards. List had a distinguished career, having made his debut in the league code in Auckland for the Kingsland club in 1921 and gaining both New Zealand and Auckland representative honors. He played all three tests for New Zealand against England in 1932, with his greatest game coming in the second match at Christchurch, where he stood out as the best of the New Zealand backs. List retired from the sport in 1942, having played for 30 seasons. He passed away on April 17, 1959, at the age of 56.
